Quoting "Heath, Joseph" <HeathJ@...>:

> JUnit doesnt guarantee the order of the tests. Your tests shouldnt rely
> on
> other tests being executed before them.

True, you shouldn't depend on the order of execution of tests, but if you must 
(and sometimes it's just easier that way), you *can* control the order in which 
tests are run.

Understand that you don't have to name your test methods "testX". That was a 
convention that became a standard, leading to a convenience feature in xUnit. 
You can always build your test suite by hand:

public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
    public static Test suite() {
        final TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
        suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod1"));
        suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod2"));
        suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod3"));
        suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod4"));
    }
    ...
}

DOWNSIDE: You must keep the suite up to date as you change the test methods in 
the test case. You will forget. It will cause you problems. If those problems 
are small compared to your current problem, then you should consider doing 
this; otherwise, you should take the time to learn about your design by 
exploring how to remove the dependency.

> > I'm currently developing JUnitEE for use with a J2EE 
> > application, and admit to being relatively new to J2EE and 
> > JUnit. However, I am getting problems running test suites as 
> > the order of execution does not appear to be constant. 
<snip />
